abusenius - (14:23): is there already something like login/logout events accessible from a component?  
tmortagne - (14:24): abusenius: no (not that i know of)  
sdumitriu - (14:25): abusenius: Hard to have those  
abusenius - (14:25): I guess the authentication must be reimplemented as a component first?  
sdumitriu - (14:25): You can just catch when a user explicitly uses the login logout form  
sdumitriu - (14:25): Normally the cookies are checked each time, and cookies are there for a long time  
sdumitriu - (14:26): So, how do you define a login?  
abusenius - (14:26): well, authentication  
abusenius - (14:26): user provided credentials = login  
tmortagne - (14:28): abusenius: so make authenticator produce an event each time it's called ?  
abusenius - (14:29): is the authenticator the only way a user can login?  
abusenius - (14:29): in my case, I want to clear the cache with secret tokens when the user logs out  
abusenius - (14:29): but I think this is a good idea also in general, other components might use it too  
tmortagne - (14:31): login generally calls an authenticator so yes AFAIK when you log in you always call an authenticator at some point  
tmortagne - (14:32): that's the easiest way i see to have login events, now for logout it probably not that simple  
abusenius - (14:32): and logout too?  
tmortagne - (14:32): problem is hat you don't always explicitely logout  
tmortagne - (14:32): in fact most of the time you don't  
abusenius - (14:32): true, cookies can just expiere  
abusenius - (14:32): or you crash  
tmortagne - (14:32): yep you can only have dome daemon thread doing checks  
tmortagne - (14:33): s/dome/some/  
abusenius - (14:33): maybe I should expire tokens too, this will keep the cache small too

CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:02): I'm going to commit some more test stuff, I changed some of the loginAndGotoPage methods to getURLToLoginAndGotoPage.  
abusenius - (15:12): is there a standard way to fire some "PeriodicEvent" every couple of hours?  
arkub joined #xwiki at 15:12  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:13): I don't think there is a standard, doesn't sound too difficult though.  
tmortagne - (15:13): abusenius: there is no timer events at component level but you can use scheduler plugin to call java code periodically  
CalebJamesDeLisl - (15:14): Going to commit tests for Invitation Application. They're @Ignored for now since Invitation is still sandboxed.  
tmortagne - (15:14): jvdrean would know better  
jvdrean - (15:15): abusenius: yes, the scheduler plugin (Scheduler.WebHome) allows to create periodic jobs  
jvdrean - (15:16): those jobs can fire a groovy script or order the execution of an implementation of a quartz job present in the classpath  
abusenius - (15:18): thx, hm.. just wondering whether this is a good way to be the main source of periodic events for a component  
abusenius - (15:19): its not a script or optional application, but rather meant to be used everywhere  
jvdrean - (15:37): abusenius: the answer I think is that the scheduler plugin should be rewritten as a component
